title: Spain's government will exhume dictator Francisco Franco's body from his mausoleum on Thursday
text:
Spain's former military dictator Francisco Franco's remains will be dug up this week and relocated to his family tomb on the edge of the city of Madrid.

The Spanish government has announced its plans to exhume the former general's body from the colossal mausoleum at the Valley of the Fallen, where it has been interred since his death in 1975.

Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez has long said relocating Franco's body was needed to heal the wounds of the Spanish civil war and transform the memorial into one that commemorates victims instead of glorifying a fascist regime.

The Valle de los Caidos (The Valley of the Fallen), a monument to the Francoist combatants who died during the Spanish civil war and Spain's General Francisco Franco's mausoleum

In a statement issued today the Spanish Government said Franco's remains would be taken from the 20th-century memorial site to a discreet grave close to the capital by helicopter on Thursday.

Today's announcement comes after the Supreme Court, in September, granted the ruling Socialist Party's bid to get the body moved - despite objections by Franco's family.

The judges rejected Franco's relatives' earlier appeal against the Socialist government's plan to remove the body from the Valley of the Fallen and move it to the family tomb at the Mingorrubio El Pardo.

He will be buried alongside his wife in the cemetery north of Madrid.

The late dictator's family will attend the removal of his remains from the monument's central basilica on Thursday morning.

Preparations are already underway for the planned exhumation of Francisco Franco's body. Civil guards can be seen checking the papers of workers arriving at the Valley of the Fallen where his remains are currently interred

Guards at the entry of the Valley of the Fallen monitor traffic in and out of the site as it is closed ahead of Francisco Franco's body being exhumed on Thursday

Neither media nor the general public will be allowed to watch the the proceedings on Thursday.

In preparation the Government has shut the Valley of the Fallen and traffic in and out of the memorial is being monitored.

The relocation of Franco's tomb continues to fracture Spanish opinion with 43 per cent in favour of the move and 32.5 per cent against, according to a poll published by El Mundo last week.

Franco ruled Spain with an iron first after victory in the civil war in 1939 until his death in 1975.

He remains a contentious political touchstone in Spain and the tomb was seen by many as glorifying a fascist regime and its members.

General Francisco Franco (1892-1975)

The Socialists have long sought to turn the Valley of the Fallen into a memorial to victims of the civil war, unleashed by Franco, in which about 500,000 people were killed.

Nearly 34,000 dead from the civil war are buried there, including many who fought for the losing Republican side and whose bodies were transferred to the site during Franco's dictatorship without the permission of families.

Franco's family had appealed both against exhuming his remains and against the government's plans to move them to the El Pardo cemetery.

Were his remains to be moved, they wanted them to go to the Almudena Roman Catholic Cathedral adjacent to the Royal Palace in central Madrid, alongside his daughter.

A government report said last December that the Almudena cathedral, located right in the centre of Madrid not far from the royal palace, was unsuitable as a burial place for security reasons.

A visitor to the Valley of the Fallen makes a Nazi salute while standing in front of the central facade
